metaData.descriptionCS: The examinee performs simple tasks in a number of different areas including orientation to time, mental control, clock drawing, incidental recall, automaticity and inhibitory control, and verbal production.

choiceList.question: What day of the week is this?
What day of the month is this?
Who is the current president of the United States?

questions.title: Clock Drawing Item 9-1 (Numbers)
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Open the Response Booklet to the page marked Brief Cognitive Status Exam — Item 9 and place the Response Booklet and a pencil with no eraser in front of the examinee.

You must observe the examinee as he or she draws in order to record appropriately.

Say, Draw the face of a clock, put in the numbers, and set the hands to 10 minutes after nine.
 
Do not allow the examinee to erase or restart the drawing. If the examinee attempts to erase or restart, say, Do not start over. Just do your best.

When the examinee is finished drawing, remove the Response Booklet and pencil. 

Score examinee's drawing sequence.

data.processScoringHtml:
Hour marks are not required but are considered acceptable substitutes for numbers in the criteria below.

Roman numerals are acceptable.

If no numbers or hour marks are present, score all Numbers criteria 0 points.

processScoringCriteria.title: Numbers-Sequence
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
2 points: The 12, 3, 6, 9 anchors (or hour marks representing 12, 3, 6, 9) are drawn first and then the remaining numbers or hour marks are placed correctly.

  • The anchor numbers may be drawn in any order.

1 point: The numbers 1–12 are recorded in serial order.

  • Recording number 12 first, followed by 1, 2, 3... 11 is acceptable.
  • Reverse serial order (e.g., 12, 11, 10... 1) is acceptable.
  • If the examinee begins with any number (e.g., 3), then continues from that number in serial order or reverse serial order, it is acceptable.
  • Recording exactly 12 hour marks in a serial clockwise or counterclockwise manner is acceptable.

0 points: The 12, 3, 6, 9 anchors are not drawn first or the numbers 1–12 or exactly 12 hour marks are not recorded in serial order or reverse serial order.

  • If numbers other than 1–12 are recorded (e.g., 1–15), if all of the numbers 1–12 are not recorded (e.g., 1–10 only), if exactly 12 hour marks are not present, or if a number is repeated, Numbers–Sequence should receive 0 points.

processScoringCriteria.title: Numbers-Presence
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
1 point: The numbers 1–12 are recorded.

  • The numbers may be recorded in any sequence.
  • Exactly 12 hour marks are acceptable. See 1a.
  • Any combination of exactly 12 numbers (1–12 only) and hour marks are acceptable. See 1b.

0 points: The numbers 1–12 are not recorded, any numbers other than 1–12 are recorded, any number within 1–12 is recorded more than once, exactly 12 hour marks are not present.

 

1a 1b

processScoringCriteria.title: Numbers-Location
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
1 point: All numbers or hour marks present are recorded inside or on top of the contour.

  • Do not penalize the examinee for missing or extra numbers or hour marks.
  • If a number or hour mark is recorded on top of the contour line, this is acceptable. See 1c.
  • If no contour is present, score 1 point if the numbers or hour marks present are recorded in a circular manner or some other reasonable configuration consistent with a clock. See 1d.

0 points: At least one number or hour mark is recorded completely outside the contour or, if no contour is present, the numbers or hour marks are not recorded in a circular manner or some other reasonable configuration consistent with a clock.

 

1c 1d

data.processScoringHtml:
If a contour is not present, score all Contour criteria 0 points.

If concentric circles are present, consider the inner circle of the concentric set to be the contour when applying criteria.

processScoringCriteria.title: Contour-Presence
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
1 point: A contour is present.

  • The contour may be any shape (e.g., heart-shaped, alarm clock-shaped, square-shaped, concentric circles).

0 points: No contour is present.

processScoringCriteria.title: Contour-Accommodation
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
Do not penalize the examinee for missing or extra numbers, hour marks, or hands.

1 point: The contour is large enough to accommodate all the numbers, hour marks, and hands drawn by the examinee.

0 points: The contour is not large enough to accommodate all the numbers, hour marks, and hands drawn by the examinee.

processScoringCriteria.title: Contour-Closure
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
1 point: There is no gap in the contour greater than 5 mm.

  • If the endpoints of the contour line are overlapping each other, the space between the overlapping endpoints should not be considered a gap. See 2a.

0 points: There is a gap in the contour greater than 5 mm and the endpoints of the contour line are not overlapping each other. See 2b.

2a 2b

processScoringCriteria.title: Contour-Symmetry
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
The symmetry criterion is designed to assess if poor planning or impulsive responding led to an asymmetry of the contour, which in turn resulted in a placement of the numbers that is not consistent with a typical clock face. Do not assess the symmetry of the examinee’s drawing in the context of the examinee being required to produce a near-perfect circle.

The symmetry of the contour should be based on visual inspection only (e.g., not using any magnifying device or curved edge). Never judge the symmetry of a drawing against contours drawn by other examinees.

The contour does not have to be symmetrical on the horizontal axis.

1 point: The contour is roughly symmetrical on the vertical axis. See 2c–2e.

0 points: The contour is not roughly symmetrical on the vertical axis. See 2f–2h.

2c 2d 2e
2f 2g 2h

data.processScoringHtml: If fewer than two hands are present, score all Hands criteria 0 points.

processScoringCriteria.title: Hands-Presence
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
1 point: Exactly one hour hand and one minute hand are present.

  • A third hand may be present if it is clearly representing a hand indicating time in seconds.

0 points: Fewer than two hands are present or more than three hands are present (if a third hand is present it must clearly represent a hand indicating time in seconds).

processScoringCriteria.title: Hands-Connection
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
1 point: There is not a gap greater than 12 mm between the hour and minute hands.

0 points: There is a gap greater than 12 mm between the hour and minute hands.

processScoringCriteria.title: Hands-Proportion
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
This criterion is designed to assess if the hands produced by the examinee include a short hand that would easily be judged to be an hour hand and a long hand that would easily be judged to be a minute hand. Do not use any magnifying device or ruler to measure the length of hands. Determine if the hands appear to be of different lengths by visual inspection only. If your first inclination is to measure the hands to determine if one is longer than another, then those hands should not be considered to have one hand perceptibly shorter than the other. Do not use the orientation of the hands to help judge this criterion.

1 point: One hand is perceptibly shorter than the other hand.

0 points: One hand is not perceptibly shorter than the other hand.

processScoringCriteria.title: Hands-Correct Target
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
Note. If the examinee rotates the Response Booklet, note the top of the clock drawing before attempting to score.

2 points: The hour hand (shorter) is pointing at the correct hour and the minute hand (longer) is pointing at the correct minute.

1 point: The hour hand (shorter) is pointing at the correct minute and the minute hand (longer) is pointing at the correct hour; or neither hand is perceptibly shorter than the other, but one is pointing at the correct hour and the other is pointing at the correct minute.

0 points: Either the hour hand or the minute hand is not pointing at the correct hour and minute. Neither hand is pointing at the correct hour or minute.

data.processScoringHtml: If fewer than two hands are present, a center dot or circle must be drawn by the examinee to receive 1 point on the center criteria.

processScoringCriteria.title: Center-Presence
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
Do not penalize an examinee for location on this criterion.

1 point: The clock has a center that was drawn by the examinee (see 4a), or created by the connection of the two hands, or inferred by the extrapolation to the point where two hands would meet if a gap is present (see 4b).

0 points: The clock does not have a center that was drawn by the examinee, or created by the connection of the two hands, or inferred by the extrapolation to the point where two hands would meet if a gap is present. See 4c.

 

4a 4b 4c

processScoringCriteria.title: Center-Location
processScoringCriteria.descriptionHtml:
If two hands are present, always assess the center created by the connection of the two hands or inferred by the extrapolation to the point where two hands would meet if a gap is present rather than a center dot or circle drawn by the examinee.

In 4d, both a center dot is drawn and two hands are present. In this example, the Center–Location criteria should only be applied to the center created by the two hands.

 

4d

1 point: The center or inferred center falls within the middle third of the contour.

0 points: The center or inferred center does not fall within the middle third of the contour.

questions.title: Incidental Recall Item 10
questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say, Earlier, I showed you four pictures of objects and asked you to name each one. I want you to tell me what those four objects were.

choiceList.question: Glasses
choiceList.correct: Glasses, Reading glasses, Sunglasses, Bifocals, Eyeglasses, Eyewear, Spectacles

choiceList.question: Cup
choiceList.correct: Cup, Glass, Mug, Any type of cup
